Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Rachel Racicot of Yale University to conduct a research project in Geosciences during the summer of 2013 at The National Museum of Nature and Science/Tsukuba Science Center in Tokyo and Tsukuba, Japan. The project title is "Evolution of Echolocation in Porpoises and Dolphins Elucidated from High-Resolution CT Scans Revealing Inner Ear Morphology." The host scientist is Dr. Naoki Kohno.

Living dolphins and whales (cetaceans) employ echolocation as a means of avoiding predators and finding prey; this involves a unique suite of anatomical features that allows the emission and reception of sound from parts of the ear, skull, and soft tissue structures. How porpoises and their relatives evolved echolocation is an important area of research crucial to developing more effective conservation strategies. In particular, the inner ears of these animals perform a pivotal role in both sense of space and sound reception. This project examines the evolution of echolocation in porpoises and their relatives by digitally extracting the inner ear labyrinths from computed tomographic (CT) scans of some of the earliest fossil delphinoids, and comparing them with extant species. Documenting the changing morphology of inner ears from early-diverging porpoises to extant species provides a sense for how they perceive the three-dimensional world around them. This project CT scans Fossils and recent material from museum collections in Japan and the morphology of their inner ears is digitally reconstructed using state-of-the-art software. The morphology of inner ears helps reconstruct the evolutionary relationships between modern groups of dolphins and porpoises, for which additional morphological evidence is sorely needed.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the analyses used by the Fellow employ cutting-edge CT scans and software for accurate measurement and statistical analyses. These CT data represent an increasingly important resource in the earth and natural sciences; three-dimensional analyses allow for non-destructive digital examination of internal features (which are otherwise impossible to obtain), and are permanent digital records available to future researchers, museums, and the general public via websites such as www.digimorph.org. This project will be submitted to peer-reviewed scientific journals such as the Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology, Trends in Ecology and Evolution, and Paleontological Research. The charismatic nature of marine mammals affords exceptional opportunities for public outreach, including lectures and development of educational materials. Ongoing mentorship of undergraduates at Yale in the use and interpretation of CT scans will be enhanced by this research in Japan. The Fellow will also share her experiences with the Japanese Society for Women in Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Increasing noise in the world’s oceans, caused by humans, has had severe impacts on toothed whales (‘odontocetes’), leading to mass strandings, and affecting their abilities to feed, navigate, and communicate. Central to their ability to hear (which they do via biosonar – a form of echolocation) are their inner ear labyrinths containing the cochlea and vestibule, which are contained deep within the ear bones. I collaborated with Dr. Naoki Kohno in Japan on a number of projects focusing on the inner ears of porpoises and relatives using CT scans – these data are expected to help discern the evolutionary relationships between different groups of toothed whales, and also provide insight into how echolocation evolved, and what frequencies these animals can hear. The CT scans allow digital isolation of the inner ear structures, producing detailed 3D digital imagery, and come with a number of additional advantages. Scans allow imaging of internal anatomy that would otherwise require scientists to cut up (and/or permanently alter) rare and valuable fossils, as such this technique is ‘non-destructive’. As digital images, they can be magnified and studied in detail, allowing accurate measurements of lengths, volumes, and other morphological details (such as the number of turns or tightness of coiling of the cochlea), which have previously been used to infer hearing ranges, and can also be used in statistical analyses. Finally, the 3D digital images can be further processed in engineering labs, and can be used to produce 3D printed models that can be shared and exchanged with other scientists and museums around the world. In the future, many of the world’s most valuable and rare fossils may all be scanned and 3D printed, allowing everyone access to these specimens. While in Japan I was able to scan and reconstruct a number of rare fossil and living odontocetes, some of which are unknown outside of Japan, and which represent key evolutionary transitions in their groups. Ongoing work with these specimens will soon shed light on the history of these fascinating animals, and help us to understand the reasons behind the evolution of biosonar in this group of marine mammals. Perhaps more importantly, these data will be made available to marine biologists working on the effects of anthropogenic noise on the behavior of toothed whales, and enhance efforts into their conservation. Preliminary results show that the fossil porpoise inner ear labyrinths are very similar in appearance to living species, implying that they had similar hearing frequency ranges and ecologies to modern porpoises. The CT scanner at the National Museum of Nature and Science, Tokyo, is located within the public exhibits, allowing ample opportunity to engage with Japanese and international patrons of the museum and showcase my research. Results from the work have been integral to my PhD research and for ongoing projects as part of my long-term research goals.
